Topic.Title: Sterne Agee = stupid is as stupid does

Message.Msg: I've spoken to this Vijay Rakesh guy. He is a stubborn analyst that just has an agenda. At the time, Intel was down to $12 and he was trying to push it down further. It obviously did not work too well for him. As for the more current comments he is making about low demand because of hard drive sales, it doesn't make much sense since Intel is keeping its chip prices strong. If demand was weak, Intel would have to drop prices. The latest prossesor price list released just yesterday proves Intel is seeing strong demand for its chips across the board. You would think with some weakness in PC's, Intel would drop at least one of their chip offerrings. But not one! Here's the processor price list for Intel. As anyone can clearly see, Intel has not and is still not dropping any of its chip prices. Strong demand obviously for Intel products. Not so strong for AMD because Intel seems to be the processor of choice. http://files.shareholder.com/downloads/INTC/1676228748x0x586838/93FD9F7A-F52F-4DCC-9498-F9D055E08830/Copy_of_July_29_12_Recommended_Customer_Price_List.pdf

Message.Title: zack's downgrades intel
Message.Msg: http://finance.yahoo.com/news/zacks-bull-bear-day-highlights-114828747.html

>>>Intel Corp. (INTC) beat the Zacks Consensus by $0.04 in the second quarter, driven by strength in server and software businesses and supported by a moderate PC business. Guidance disappointed, however, due to lower builds at distributors. Intel also remains a laggard in the mobile segment, and although its situation could improve by virtue of its Ultrabook and agreement with Google, Intel has yet to prove itself here. In the meantime, competition from ARM-based devices continues to intensify. Therefore, given the PC market weakness and the fact that mobile devices will continue to eat into its client business, we downgrade Intel shares from Neutral to Underperform. We are setting a target price of $24.00, which is 10.0X our earnings expectations for 2012<<<

Intel is subject to heavy dividend arbitraging. Expect a strong likelihood that Friday AM, Intel will open trading at $25.80. Just my theory but, it appears that the option market maker has a $26 target in his sites. The last dividend, there was 10mil to 20mil shares arbitraged using several hundred thousand options. Look for strange trading patterns today and tomorrow in a narrow plus/minus dividend range as they settle share purchases. I think that it is entirely possible that the drop from $29 was part of the preparation for tomorrows storm. They will be buying low premium in the money calls today and tomorrow, exercising early and then using long put options to guarantee a disposal price. NOTE: If you wrote covered calls that have a low premium, be prepared for the shares to be called away before the dividend is awarded. Roll the calls out to add premium protection or close them out.
The one that I like is Nomura, Romit Shah. He has a REDUCE rating and recommends a SHORT of Intel. His target price is: $25. Talk about strange advice.
It's been a very long time since we've seen a message like this.

Message.Title: Intel to make Apple chips?
Message.Msg: Another big Apple announcement set for Sep 12. Speculation is that is will be the iPhone 5. There won't be an iPhone 6 for another year. Does anyone believe that Apple will run for another year with Samsung as the "A" chip supplier? If not, who becomes the new supplier? TSMC:)? Global Foundries? In my mind the Samsung relationship has to be ending and I think it ends completely on Sep 12. Intel and the rumor mill have simply been too quiet for there NOT to be a giant upheaval in the near future. If Apple and Intel aren't kissing and hugging, Intel will soon be making mobile chips for Samsung. I think it will be the Apple design with Arm core(S) to begin with. As time moves on and as Otellini says, Intel designed products will have to become "compelling" enough to be used by Apple. If 22nm, going to 14nm next year and the only roadmap in the industry to 450mm wafers isn't "compelling" I don't know what to say.
Thought Qualcom was said to be coming in the Iphone 5 ?

I think that you are right. There are a number of suppliers coming online with 28nm fab capacity. I think that Intel provides Apple with more value as a club to beat their suppliers over the head for concessions. To paraphrase a potential AAPL-vendor conversation: "Oh, you can't do that? I guess I will just take the Intel offer." Are There Enough Chips For A Robust iPhone 5 Launch? July 30, 2012 http://seekingalpha.com/article/762381-are-there-enough-chips-for-a-robust-iphone-5-launch?source=yahoo
Interesting idea... If INtel fabs Apple chips, INtel will be fab ARM SOCs... Where does that place INtel in ARM vs x86... ??
by going out of business and leaving INtel to single source x86... Does VIA count ??

Mobile phone users have welcomed the iPhone. To build such a product, Apple needs to control all aspects of its form and function down to the design of the Ax SOCs. Delegating this design to Intel is highly unlikely. The last generation iPhone with a 45nm chip is still selling reasonably well today. What makes you think Apple is desperate for 22nm/14nm. With cost/xsistor going up because of process complexity, it's unclear how much demand there will be for these geometries over 32/28. Lower power and higher clock frequencies don't always win over cost. Higher volume markets like India and China are a lot more cost sensitive.
" Lower power and higher clock frequencies don't always win over cost." A5 is twice the size of Tegra 3... Apple makes back their costs with app royalties...

Topic.Title: Whats Moving INTC into a Blazing Stock...

Message.Msg: The market is weird. Every time one guy sells, another one buys, and they both think they're smart & that's how the market goes. You have to decide on which part you'll play! One thing is for sure that this journal helps me a lot to invest securely. I think it'll help you too.
Report: Samsung ramping Apple's A6 chip http://www.eetimes.com/electronics-news/4229790/Samsung-ramping-Apple-A6-chips

Report: Samsung ramping Apple's A6 chip http://www.eetimes.com/electronics-news/... _________________________________ You crucify me for posting an old article........and then out of the other side of your mouth you post this article from 2011. You sir, are a hypocrite with no spine. Practice what you preach, ya FRAUD.

The only way that it would make sense for Intel to fab ARM processors is if there was some long term agreement where ARM would be replaced by X86 in some proprietary way down the road. I own CRUS as well (what a fabless tech company?). The stock jumped 25% yesterday after announcing a record quarter and more to follow. They make the sound hardware for iPhones. They eluded to getting some very large order from Apple recently. So, whatever the problem was with the iPhone and CPU's it's been solved now as far as I can tell. Apple is ramping up for something huge. Though it's unlikely to be Intel I am not ready to take that possibility off the table.

I was just suggesting that Intel and Intel rumors were likely being used by Apple to gain concessions (whether spoken or unspoken). You never know when a rumor is really a rumor or intentionally planted disinformation. Intel has much IP invested in the x86 and is likely 100% commited to it. Intel has ARM licenses and a number of hetro-CPU patents awarded that enable them to do a number of things. However, I have no idea what the execs at Apple nor Intel really think or are planning outside what is public. My access to Digitimes is through the media. 8-) Inside Apple, there are divisions/groups who are competing with each other. The MAC PC group and the iPad tablet groups are competing with each other for the best product right at the x86/ARM event horizon. The MAC exec is probably proposing lower end MACs that overlap the iPad high end and the reverse. Intel (with products and delivery) must make the MAC group inside Apple more successful than the iPad group. If the MAC group skunkworks iPad86 is better enough than the iPad group offering, then it may persude management to make a shift. It will take a long time, if ever.

> Mobile phone users have welcomed the iPhone. To build such a product, Apple needs to control > all aspects of its form and function down to the design of the Ax SOCs. Delegating this > design to Intel is highly unlikely. This is a clear "Make-or-Buy" decision. (a) If/When Apple finds that Intel has made the progression to build great low-power mobile chips; (b) that it (Apple) need not invest huge amount of resources/efforts/dollars to keep up with Intel's SoC and Process roadmaps along with associated risks; and (c) that it is rather onerous and risky to rely on Samsung, TSMC, etc. Then Apple will make the transition to Intel. We don't know where Intel/Apple are in each of the above. In terms of design uniqueness, Intel has already shown a willingness to build custom SoCs for large partners. > The last generation iPhone with a 45nm chip is still selling reasonably well today. > What makes you think Apple is desperate for 22nm/14nm. With cost/xsistor going up > because of process complexity, it's unclear how much demand there will be for these > geometries over 32/28. Lower power and higher clock frequencies don't always win over > cost. Higher volume markets like India and China are a lot more cost sensitive. Selling well today - is all fine and dandy. But this is about the future. Apple has to evolve its products to maintain its image as a cutting edge company. Customers don't care about 32/28/22/14nm - but they have shown that they love smaller devices that can do more and more. Initial adoption for these smaller geometries (with higher costs) will be by consumers in advanced countries - as volumes increase and costs come down, there will be sufficiently big markets in emerging economies as well. With each smaller process node and increased wafer size, the complexity and capital costs do go up - but cost per unit comes down drastically. Otherwise, no vendor would even have a roadmap to transition to smaller nodes and larger wafer sizes! Intel and the chip industry have a track record in innovating to smaller geometries (and larger wafers). I would give them credit that they know what they are doing.
"The MAC PC group and the iPad tablet groups are competing with each other for the best product right at the x86/ARM event horizon." That's so Apple !!!!

Message.Title: Make-or-Buy Decision for Apple
Message.Msg: I could think of the following considerations Apple would have in transition to x86-based Tablets and Smartphones: (a) Intel's progress and roadmap to build great low-power mobile chips; (b) Investment by Apple in terms of resources/efforts/dollars to keep up with Intel's SoC and Process roadmaps along with associated risks; and (c) Risk involved in relaying on Samsung, TSMC, or other foundries. Medfield has been a good starting point for (a) above. Two more chips - one higher and one lower than current Medfield have been announced by Intel which will provide more evidence of Intel's capabilities. In terms of (b), the investment has to be significant. Further, several people from Apple's ARM design team have left over the last year to 18 months. Apple is fully capable of replacing them with new talent. But does it want to continue the race with Intel, especially since Intel is offering custom SoCs based on x86 (and ARM for starters). Regarding (c), there is clear evidence that Apple's relationship with Samsung is not optimal. TSMC has not been dependable in terms of process or capacity for Qualcomm, nVidia, et al...they are looking to source from other foundries. Would Apple want to continue on this path? We'll see.
